newsitem.title: USA: Magnesium prices seen steady, output rising.
newsitem.headline: Magnesium prices seen steady, output rising.

text.p: Magnesium prices are expected to remain steady over the coming year, with only a little upward pressure as more metal comes on stream, said Andrew Lubin, president of Midland Export Limited.

More recycling capacity in the United States will encourage greater imports of magnesium alloy, lessening domestic consumer dependency on U.S. producers, Lubin told an aluminum industry conference in Chicago.
More primary magnesium capacity was also coming on stream.
Israel's new Dead Sea Magnesium works will begin pouring hot metal within two weeks, and plans to export commercial quantities of primary magnesium by the second quarter of next year, Lubin said.
Most of the metal from the Dead Sea Works will go to Volkswagen AG, Lubin added.
Following a price surge in magnesium in 1993 and 1994, the supply and demand pendulum was swinging back to the consumer's side, Lubin said.
"With a few more suppliers from whom to choose, perhaps the wild market gyrations of the last few years will be moderated," Lubin said.
"And if the swings are moderated, then perhaps the consumers, who are predominantly aluminum and automotive, can be induced to use more magnesium," he added.
Growth in magnesium consumption should equal economic growth over the next few years.
"I will forecast that primary magnesium prices will continue to rise slowly, but with the proviso that the primary aluminum market remains at current or higher levels," Lubin said.
Magnesium alloy prices should remain at current levels, he added. Magnesium currently trades at around $2,600 a tonne, while aluminum sells for about $1,535 a tonne.
